description:
Plasmodium vinckei vinckei is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Plasmodium. It is a species of malaria parasite that primarily infects rodents, specifically the African thicket rat (Grammomys surdaster) and the African striped mouse (Rhabdomys pumilio).

Plasmodium vinckei vinckei is a subspecies of Plasmodium vinckei, which was first discovered in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (formerly Zaire) in the 1950s. The subspecies P. v. vinckei is found in certain regions of Central and West Africa.

Like other Plasmodium species, P. v. vinckei has a complex life cycle that involves both a vertebrate host (the rodent) and an invertebrate host (a mosquito vector, typically from the genus Anopheles). The parasite is transmitted between hosts through the bite of an infected mosquito, which introduces the parasite's sporozoite stage into the host's bloodstream.

Once inside the rodent host, the parasites undergo a series of developmental stages, including the liver stage and the blood stage, ultimately leading to the production of new merozoites that can infect additional red blood cells. This cyclical pattern of infection and replication within the host's body is characteristic of malaria parasites.

Plasmodium vinckei vinckei serves as a useful model organism for the study of malaria pathogenesis, host-parasite interactions, and the development of potential antimalarial drugs and therapies, as it is closely related to the human malaria parasites but is not infectious to humans.
